data.text: how-do-you-keep-your-phone-charged-more-than-a-day-when-touring.md

How do people keep their phone on charge for more than a day without plugging on mains ? I have a front dynamo 6v 3 w with my phone on charge and the charge keeps falling throughout the day with nearly nothing at the end of day. I must admit the screen is nearly on max brightness so I can see it in the sun. I am not connected to media/internet while cycling and my maps are downloaded to avoid internet connection. Thank for any help ..
Small portable battery. Charges several devices at once.

data.author: Martin Hughes

data.text: A phone screen on maximum brightness will draw too much current. Far better off using a purpose built navigation device, designed to have the map on all day. And I agree with that it is better to use a portable battery, to charge the phone, if you really must use it in that way. The only draw back with using the dynamo via a rectifier to power the Garmin / whatever nav device you get, is that at low speeds you may get warnings that the external power source has been disconnected. Not normally a problem, but you might want to disconnect it on a steep ascent!
data.author: Jef Ott

data.text: Use a powerbank. A dynamo generates AC that need to be converted to DC and have a usb stabilization to 5V. In theory you can get a maximum 600mA charging current after conversion, but 100% efficiency is not possibe, so, in best case scenario you will get a maximum of 550mA. In most cases that's below the power consumption of a phone with maximum display brightness. Also, keep in mind that output power of most dynamo is 3W at speeds that exceed 25 or 30 km/h. Riding slower means lower output power. And, another thing, some phones have a built in safety protocol that stops charging process if there are fluctuations in charging current.

data.text: New phones like iPhone use much more power. I have a dynamo hub and usb charger that charged everything (not just my phone) all day. This year with the new phone I had to replace the usb charger for more power, and installed a forumslader. Works great!

data.text: I do a few things. 1) I put the phone on the power saving mode as much as possible. 2) Put on airplane mode at all times with wifi and bluetooth off 3) Keep the phone cool as much as possible 4) Bring a backup Anker 20,000 mAh battery

data.author: Daniel Hanyu Hirose

data.text: - If you're using it for navigation, only touch the screen on when you need it, like when you reach a junction in the road. The screen is the biggest battery drain. - Make sure that all the systems you're not using - wifi, nfc, bluetooth etc. are switched off if you're not using them. Or, even better... - Use airplane mode - this switches off all the phone's aerials except the gps. Your phone can use a lot of power connecting to a signal if you're far away from cellphone towers. Only turn off airplane mode when you need to use the phone or connect to the internet. - If you need to be available by phone but don't need internet, switch off the data connection. - If you need to be data connected, use your phones power-saving mode. This will limit the background data connections your phone makes. - Check your battery usage for any misbehaving apps that are draining your battery unnecessarily. - Use another phone for navigation. Ulefone, Doogee, Blackview, Oukitel make rugged, waterproof phones with over 10,000 mAh batteries that will easily last multiple days.
